The "Social Security Solvency Act of 2009" may be cited as the Act. It includes progressive indexing of benefits for old-age insurance benefits. The "Social Security Solvency Act of 2009" includes amendments to Section 215(a) of the Social Security Act, specifying changes in benefit calculations for individuals eligible for old-age insurance benefits from 2012 onwards. The "Social Security Solvency Act of 2009" amends benefit calculations for old-age insurance recipients, with earnings capped at certain amounts based on indexed monthly earnings. For calendar year 2012, the amount established is determined by the Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration at the 30th percentile for the period of calendar years 2001 through 2003. The amount established for calendar year 2012 is determined by the Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration at the 30th percentile for the period of calendar years 2001 through 2003. The formula for calculating the maximum wage-indexed benefit amount for any calendar year involves specific percentages determined in preceding years. In non-positive balance years, adjustments are made by substituting the second calendar year before the most recent positive balance year. The maximum wage-indexed benefit amount is based on an individual's wages and self-employment income in each computation base year. The maximum CPI-indexed benefit amount for any calendar year is calculated based on specific ratios of the Consumer Price Index and national wage index for preceding years. A positive balance year is defined as a calendar year after 2050 certified by the Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration. The combined balance ratio of the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund must be at least 100 percent for the year. The ratio is calculated based on the combined balance of the Trust Funds at the end of the calendar year, minus any transfers, compared to the estimated amount to be paid from the Trust Funds in the following year. The term 'applicable benefit' refers to any benefit under section 202 except for specific circumstances related to child's insurance, widow's insurance, and widower's insurance. Modification of PIA factors to reflect changes in life expectancy. Modification of PIA factors to reflect changes in life expectancy. Section 215(a)(2) of the Social Security Act is amended to adjust percentages for individuals eligible for old-age insurance benefits after 2017 based on life expectancy ratios. The Commissioner of Social Security will determine these adjustments through the Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration. The Social Security Administration's Actuary determines and publishes the life expectancy ratio annually. This ratio compares an individual's life expectancy at age 67 based on death rates from different years. Amendments are made to adjust percentages for old-age insurance benefits based on these ratios. The Commissioner of Social Security will conduct a study on creating a separate life expectancy ratio for disabled beneficiaries attaining early retirement age. A report on the study results will be submitted to Congress within one year of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. TREATMENT OF DISABLED BENEFICIARIES. Section 215(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include provisions for individuals with a period of disability becoming eligible for old-age insurance benefits. The primary insurance amount is calculated based on specific criteria outlined in the amendment. The primary insurance amount for individuals with a period of disability becoming eligible for old-age insurance benefits is determined based on specific criteria outlined in the amendment. The adjustment factor for each individual is calculated as the ratio of the total number of months under disability to the period from age 22 to the first month of eligibility for old-age insurance benefits. The primary insurance amount for individuals eligible for old-age insurance benefits is determined based on specific criteria outlined in the amendment, including the number of months under disability compared to the period from age 22 to the first month of eligibility. SEC. 5. ACCELERATION OF INCREASE IN RETIREMENT AGE: The retirement age under the Social Security Act is amended to increase to 67 by 2016. 

SEC. 6. MAINTENANCE OF ADEQUATE BALANCES IN THE SOCIAL SECURITY TRUST FUNDS. The Social Security Act is amended to appropriate necessary funds to maintain the balance ratio of the Trust Funds at not less than 100 percent each fiscal year. The Commissioner of Social Security determines and certifies these sums to Congress by October 1 of each fiscal year. The Commissioner of Social Security determines and certifies necessary funds to maintain the Trust Funds balance ratio at 100 percent each fiscal year using actuarial assumptions. The certification is transmitted to the Secretary of the Treasury for appropriate actions. The amendment applies to fiscal years after the enactment of the Act.
